{{Main|Morality and religion}} {{See also|Divine command theory|Morality without religion|Secular ethics}}
 
{{Main|Morality and religion}} {{See also|Divine command theory|Morality without religion|Secular ethics}}
    −
Religion and morality are not synonymous. Morality does not depend upon religion although this is "an almost automatic assumption." <ref>{{cite book | last1 = Rachels| first1 = (ed) James | last2 = Rachels | first2 = (ed) Stuart | title = The Elements of Moral Philosophy | publisher = McGraw-Hill| edition = 7 | year = 2011| location = New York| page = | isbn = 0-078-03824-3}}</ref> According to ''The Westminster Dictionary of Christian Ethics'', religion and morality "are to be defined differently and have no definitional connections with each other. Conceptually and in principle, morality and a religious value system are two distinct kinds of value systems or action guides."<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Childress| first1 = (ed) James F. | last2 = Macquarrie| first2 = (ed) John | title = The Westminster Dictionary of Christian Ethics | publisher = The Westminster Press| edition = | year = 1986| location = Philadelphia| page = 401| isbn = 0-664-20940-8}}</ref> Though there are no connections between Religion and Morality, by definition, it can be said that religious values can influence one's stance on morality. The perceived view of what is considered right and wrong is drawn from experience and what we view to be truth.
+
Religion and morality are not synonymous. Morality does not depend upon religion although this is "an almost automatic assumption." <ref>{{cite book | last1 = Rachels| first1 = (ed) James | last2 = Rachels | first2 = (ed) Stuart | title = The Elements of Moral Philosophy | publisher = McGraw-Hill| edition = 7 | year = 2011| location = New York| page = | isbn = 0-078-03824-3}}</ref> According to ''The Westminster Dictionary of Christian Ethics'', religion and morality "are to be defined differently and have no definitional connections with each other. Conceptually and in principle, morality and a religious value system are two distinct kinds of value systems or action guides."<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Childress| first1 = (ed) James F. | last2 = Macquarrie| first2 = (ed) John | title = The Westminster Dictionary of Christian Ethics | publisher = The Westminster Press| edition = | year = 1986| location = Philadelphia| page = 401| isbn = 0-664-20940-8}}</ref>
